title: 108_hr4938
content: The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2004" requires certain organizations to disclose their lobbying activities. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2004" mandates disclosure of lobbying activities for coalitions or associations identified as clients under the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995. They are treated as separate political organizations for tax purposes. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2004" requires disclosure of lobbying activities for coalitions or associations identified as clients under the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995. Lobbying activities are treated as exempt functions, with specific deductions disallowed and certain disclosure requirements applied instead. Lobbying activities do not include certain specified activities. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2004" mandates that coalitions or associations identified as political organizations must notify the Secretary within 72 hours of a lobbyist's first lobbying contact. This notification must be done electronically and in writing. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2004" requires coalitions or associations to notify the Secretary of any changes in membership within 72 hours. The notice must include information such as the name, address, and contact details of each member. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2004" mandates coalitions or associations to inform the Secretary of any membership changes within 72 hours. The notice should include a general description of each member's business or activities and the expected contribution towards influencing legislation. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2004" requires coalitions or associations to notify the Secretary of any membership changes promptly. Failure to provide the required notice or include accurate information will result in a penalty equal to the specified tax rate multiplied by the amount involved. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2004" mandates prompt notification to the Secretary of membership changes by coalitions or associations. Failure to do so incurs penalties based on the amount involved, which includes expected payments or contributions by members towards activities. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2004" requires coalitions or associations to promptly notify the Secretary of membership changes. Members are jointly and severally liable for any failure to disclose, with penalties assessed and collected similarly to other tax penalties. Certain tax-exempt associations are exempt from this requirement. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2004" mandates prompt notification to the Secretary of membership changes for coalitions or associations. Certain tax-exempt associations are exempt from this requirement, with exceptions for members of a coalition or association from disclosure in specific cases. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2004" requires prompt notification to the Secretary of membership changes for coalitions or associations. Members contributing over $2,200 per year towards influencing legislation are treated as new members if not initially disclosed. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2004" mandates timely notification to the Secretary of membership changes for coalitions or associations. Look-thru rules apply to political organizations, where coalitions or associations are considered as employing or retaining individuals for lobbying activities. Information on these entities does not need to be included in disclosure notices. The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2004" requires timely notification to the Secretary of membership changes for coalitions or associations.
